headline: Thanksgiving Turkey Brine
description: This easy turkey brine recipe makes this year's Thanksgiving turkey the juiciest and most flavorful one you have ever prepared.
name: Thanksgiving Turkey Brine
recipeIngredient: 2 gallons ice, divided, or more as needed
1 (20 pound) whole turkey, neck and giblets removed

recipeInstructions.text: Mix water, chicken broth, and salt together in a 5-gallon bucket with a lid until salt dissolves. Add garlic, rosemary, onion, basil, savory, marjoram, thyme, tarragon, oregano, pepper, and coriander; mix well. Stir 2 cups ice into brine.

Place turkey into brine, filling cavity with brine. Add enough ice to the bucket to cover turkey. Secure the lid on the bucket. Swish bucket from side to side to chill water. Refrigerate turkey and bucket for 12 to 24 hours; refill with ice every 2 hours as needed.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Remove turkey from brine and pat dry. Discard brine. Place turkey on a rack inside a roasting pan.

Bake turkey in the preheated oven, basting every 30 to 40 minutes, until no longer pink at the bone and the juices run clear, 5 to 6 1/2 hours. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the thigh should read 165 degrees F (74 degrees C).
Remove turkey from the oven, cover with a doubled sheet of aluminum foil, and rest for 5 to 10 minutes before slicing.

review.reviewBody: I love this turkey brine recipe. It is now my go to any time I make a turkey. I also use it for boneless turkey breast. I cut the recipe in half for that and it is always delicious.

Used recipe exactly - but marinated 20-pounder 40 hours. The ultimate in moist, tender white meat ever. And I mean Ever! And I've been baking/marinating turkeys for 54 years now! Excellent flavor as well. The Best.

Brined my 23 lb turkey in this for 24 hours and it was amazing! I couldn't find savory anywhere, so that was omitted, and I did toss in about a cup of brown sugar, but those were my only changes. Turkey got rave reviews!

This is a wonderful Turkey Brine.....I love it!
It makes your Turkey taste delicious & savory

By far the BEST turkey I have ever made. I did follow Alton Brown's roasting directions (500F) for the first 30 min and then down to 350F for the remainder. I kept min covered until the last 15 min to brown it up. Even those who dont' care for turkey because they find it too dry - LOVED this! Juicy and so much flavor!

Absolutely delicious results using this recipe although I did not have all the spices on hand (no savory, marjoram, tarragon, or coriander seed) but I can't imagine adding these missing ingredient in could do anything but make it more delicious. The turkey was very moist not to mention gorgeous when it came out of the oven. I've added this to my Thanksgiving recipes folder as it will be used for each and every Thanksgiving from now on.
I should have taken photo

This brine makes the best turkey ever. Definately worth it as written. 
 Debbie
Very good!!
This is a great brine and makes the turkey more moist.

I used this brine for my Thanksgiving ?? and oh my goodness it was seriously the best turkey I've ever made.. so delicious juicy and tender.. I eyeballed the seasonings because my turkey was 20lb and it still turned out perfect I will definitely be using this recipe again and again

I had never brined a turkey before but this was absolutely wonderful. It was moist and very flavorful. I simmered just enough water (4-6 cups) to dissolve the salt and to release the flavors of the spices, allowed to cool for about an hour then added ice to quick chill the brine, immersed the turkey into the brine adding more water and covered with more ice. Put it in the garage for 24 hours, keeping an eye on how quickly the ice was melting and adding more as needed. WOW.....the best.
Modifiers: I used vegetable broth, onion powder and coriander powder. The turkey turned out very good (but I also rubbed spices before roasting)

Awesome brining recipe, fused this recipe with another roasting focused recipe on ‘all recipes’ specially for stuffing inside turkey and around the roasting pot. Turned out to be really good, even got compliments from my wife who dislikes turkey.
AMAZING!! I let it sit int he brine over 24 hours. Also we covered the turkey with bacon.
I have used this brine for the 3 years for our Thanksgiving turkey and it always turns out perfect.
Amazing better than any brine I've ever done. Thanks for sharing!!
The breast should be cooked to 165 F and the thigh 175. I believe the author of this recipe should check USDA recommendation for safe cooking temp.
I would never ever make a turkey and other way. It came out absolutely perfect. I cooked it upside down for the first half. Magnificent!
Loved This! Highly recommended!!!

Will use this brine again! I did not have the coriander seeds, but everything else combined made it delicious smelling and our bird was very juicy. Soaked for about 20 hours and it was a 13 pound turkey. Cooked ours on the grill with a smoker box. Super super yummy!

I have tried many turkey brines over the past few years but nothing can compare to this recipe. Most of the brines I have tried are sweet. This one is savory. It enhances the flavor of the turkey instead of masking it with sugar.
This is now my go-to recipe for roast turkey!
Lots of good flavors!!

My turkey brined for 19 hours. Best turkey I've ever eaten. So flavorful and juicy. After brining, I stuffed mine with a cornbread stuffing. I'll never cook another turkey without brining it first. No more dry, flavorless turkeys! Now I know.
Rave reviews from the family. They want future turkeys made this way. Juicy with great flavor. So glad to have tried this recipe.

My turkey turned out so juicy and it tasted amazing I will definitely be using this brine from now on, even better the drippings were so flavorful that I didn't have to add any additional spices to flavor the gravy.

Nice Balanced flavors! I made a small modification in the technique. In a quart of the water, I dissolved the salt and added the spices and brought it to a boil then simmered for 5 minutes to open up the flavors more. Then in a large brining container, poured the cooled spices over half of a 7.5 pound bag of ice (approximately a gallon of water). Adding the bird, I then mixed in more ice to keep it cool.
this was absolutely delicious.. i cut the servings down to 5 and used it on a whole chicken.. only deviation was leaving out the tarragon and ice.. will be making this again.. ty for the recipe
I put in 1 tablespoon of Cayenne pepper and it came out GREAT

I made this and it was tasty. I also smoked the turkey on my primo smoker grill. They next time I mite soak the wood chips in advance and use the beautiful Amber water that the wood chips leave behind after soaking and see if that gives the turkey that little extra yum. Not sure if this is ok so if anybody has tried this before would be nice to know ahead of time.

OMG this is the best brine EVER! I used for the first Thanksgiving turkey I ever cooked (2014). It was so good, my sister told me I was in charge of the turkey every year from now on!! This will be my go-to brine from now on!!
Wow! Simply amazing blend of flavors which work so well together. I'll be passing this recipe onto my children's children!
I made this recipe for Thanksgiving last year and it was a hit. I will do the same again this year. The turkey was really juicy and had a good flavor.
Just added a cup of sugar to the brine. Let that bad boy soak in the brine slather on the butter and roasted slow. sooo juicy!!!!!

This was the first year I brined a turkey! This was so good!! The only thing I left out was the savory, I didn't have any in the pantry and the market was out! I left mine in the bucket overnight in our very chilly basement! This was a great recipe :)
thank you thank you thank you! This was awesome! So awesome that I'm doing it again for this Thanksgiving 2013.

I used Trader Joe's kosher split turkey breast and so cut this recipe to 3 servings. The turkey only sat in the brine in a freezer bag for 4 1/2 hours in the fridge, and when I put it in the oven for just a little less than 2 hours at 350 degrees, I didn't do a single thing to the meat. It turned out just great! I froze the bones from this and will do one more at least before Thanksgiving because I think this will give me the very best turkey stock for gravy on the Big T-Day! I highly suggest that people try this because it was extremely tasty. Thanks so very much, Henry! Excellent!
